<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#4D5358">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage103"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:9PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
	(continued)
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Repair and Maintenance
	Costs.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Repair and maintenance costs that do not substantially extend the life of the Corporation&#146;s plant and equipment are expensed as incurred.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Goodwill and Intangible Assets.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Goodwill represents the
	excess purchase price paid for acquired businesses over the estimated fair value of identifiable assets and liabilities. Other intangibles represent amounts assigned principally to contractual agreements and are amortized ratably over periods based
	on related contractual terms.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation&#146;s reporting units, which represent the level at which goodwill is tested for impairment, are
	based on the geographic regions of the Aggregates business. Additionally, the Cement business is a separate reporting unit. Goodwill is allocated to each reporting unit based on the location of acquisitions and divestitures at the time of
	consummation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The carrying values of goodwill and other indefinite-lived intangible assets are reviewed annually, as of October&nbsp;1, for
	impairment. An interim review is performed between annual tests if facts or circumstances indicate potential impairment. The carrying value of other amortizable intangibles is reviewed if facts and circumstances indicate potential impairment. If a
	review indicates the carrying value is impaired, a charge is recorded.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Retirement Plans and
	Postretirement Benefits.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	The Corporation sponsors defined benefit retirement plans and also provides other postretirement benefits. The Corporation recognizes the funded status, defined as the difference between the fair value of plan
	assets and the benefit obligation, of its pension plans and other postretirement benefits as an asset or liability on the consolidated balance sheets. Actuarial gains or losses that arise during the year are not recognized as net periodic benefit
	cost in the same year, but rather are recognized as a component of accumulated other comprehensive earnings or loss. Those amounts are amortized over the participants&#146; average remaining service period and recognized as a component of net
	periodic benefit cost. The amount amortized is determined using a corridor approach and represents the excess over 10% of the greater of the projected benefit obligation or pension plan assets.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Stock-Based Compensation.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	The
	Corporation has stock-based compensation plans for employees and its Board of Directors. The Corporation recognizes all forms of stock-based payments to employees, including stock options, as compensation expense. The compensation expense is the
	fair value of the awards at the measurement date and is recognized over the requisite service period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The fair value of restricted stock awards,
	incentive compensation awards and Board of Directors&#146; fees paid in the form of common stock are based on the closing price of the Corporation&#146;s common stock on the awards&#146; respective grant dates. The fair value of performance stock
	awards based on total shareholder return is determined by a Monte Carlo simulation methodology.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2016, the Corporation did not issue any stock
	options. For stock options issued prior to 2016, the Corporation uses the accelerated expense recognition method. The accelerated recognition method requires stock options that vest ratably to be divided into tranches. The expense for each tranche
	is allocated to its particular vesting period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation uses the lattice valuation model to determine the fair value of stock option
	awards. The lattice valuation model takes into account employees&#146; exercise patterns based on changes in the Corporation&#146;s stock price and other variables. The period of time for which options are expected to be outstanding, or expected
	term of the option, is a derived output of the lattice valuation model. The Corporation considers the following factors when estimating the expected term of options: vesting period of the award, expected volatility of the underlying stock,
	employees&#146; ages and external data.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Key assumptions used in determining the fair value of the stock options awarded in 2015 and 2014 were:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Based on these assumptions, the weighted-average fair value of each stock option granted was $57.71 and $43.42 for 2015
	and 2014, respectively.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#4D5358">
<B>
	Martin
	Marietta&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#0085CD">
	Page 17
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#4D5358">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage104"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:9PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
	(continued)
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The risk-free interest rate reflects the interest rate on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	zero-coupon
</FONT>
	U.S. government bonds, available at the time each option was granted, having a remaining life approximately equal to the option&#146;s expected life. The dividend yield represents the dividend rate
	expected to be paid over the option&#146;s expected life. The Corporation&#146;s volatility factor measures the amount by which its stock price is expected to fluctuate during the expected life of the option and is based on historical stock price
	changes. Forfeitures are required to be estimated at the time of grant and revised, if necessary, in subsequent periods if actual forfeitures differ from those estimates. The Corporation estimates forfeitures and will ultimately recognize
	compensation cost only for those stock-based awards that vest.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For restricted stock awards and incentive stock awards granted prior to 2016, the
	Corporation recognizes income tax benefits resulting from the payment of dividend equivalents on unvested stock-based payments as an increase to additional
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	paid-in
</FONT>
	capital and includes them in the pool of
	excess tax benefits. For awards granted in 2016, dividend equivalents are not paid unless the award vests.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Environmental Matters.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	The Corporation records a liability for an asset retirement obligation at fair value in the period in which it is incurred. The asset retirement obligation is recorded
	at the acquisition date of a long-lived tangible asset if the fair value can be reasonably estimated. A corresponding amount is capitalized as part of the asset&#146;s carrying amount. The fair value is affected by management&#146;s assumptions
	regarding the scope of the work required, inflation rates and quarry closure dates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Further, the Corporation records an accrual for other
	environmental remediation liabilities in the period in which it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the appropriate amounts can be estimated reasonably. Such accruals are adjusted as further information develops or circumstances
	change. These costs are not discounted to their present value or offset for potential insurance or other claims or potential gains from future alternative uses for a site.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Income Taxes.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	Deferred income taxes, net, on the consolidated balance sheets
	reflect the net tax effects of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for income tax purposes, net of valuation allowances.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Uncertain Tax Positions.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	The
	Corporation recognizes a tax benefit when it is
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	more-likely-than-not,
</FONT>
	based on the technical merits, that a tax position would be sustained upon examination by a taxing authority. The amount to be recognized
	is measured as the largest amount of tax benefit that is greater than 50% likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement with a taxing authority that has full knowledge of all relevant information. The Corporation&#146;s unrecognized tax benefits
	are recorded in other liabilities on the consolidated balance sheets or as an offset to the deferred tax asset for tax carryforwards where available.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation records interest accrued in relation to unrecognized tax benefits as income tax expense. Penalties, if incurred, are recorded as
	operating expenses in the consolidated statements of earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Sales Taxes.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	Sales taxes collected from customers are recorded as liabilities until remitted to taxing authorities and therefore are not reflected in the consolidated statements of earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Research and Development Costs.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	Research and development costs are charged to
	operations as incurred.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Start-Up
</FONT>
	Costs.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	Noncapital
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	start-up
</FONT>
	costs for new facilities and products are charged to operations as incurred.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Warranties.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	The Corporation&#146;s construction contracts contain warranty
	provisions covering defects in equipment, materials, design or workmanship that generally run from nine months to one year after project completion. Due to the nature of its projects, including contract owner inspections of the work both during
	construction and prior to acceptance, the Corporation has not experienced material warranty costs for these short-term warranties and therefore does not believe an accrual for these costs is necessary. Certain product lines carry longer warranty
	periods, for which the Corporation has accrued an estimate of warranty cost based on experience with the type of work and any known risks relative to the project. These costs were not material to the Corporation&#146;s consolidated results of
	operations for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#4D5358">
<B>
	Martin
	Marietta&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#0085CD">
	Page 18
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#4D5358">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage105"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:9PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
	(continued)
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Consolidated Comprehensive Earnings and Accumulated
	Other Comprehensive Loss.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	Consolidated comprehensive earnings for the Corporation consist of consolidated net earnings, adjustments for the funded status of pension and postretirement benefit plans, foreign currency translation
	adjustments and the amortization of the value of terminated forward starting interest rate swap agreements into interest expense, and are presented in the Corporation&#146;s consolidated statements of comprehensive earnings.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Accumulated other comprehensive loss consists of unrealized gains and losses related to the funded status
	of the pension and postretirement benefit plans, foreign currency translation and the unamortized value of terminated forward starting interest rate swap agreements, and is presented on the Corporation&#146;s consolidated balance sheets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The components of the changes in accumulated other comprehensive loss and related cumulative noncurrent deferred tax assets are as follows:
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;

</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:8PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Amounts reclassified from accumulated other comprehensive loss, net of tax
</P>
</TD>

	Total
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:2.00PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>

	$
</B>

<B>
	826&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</B>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:2.00PT SOLID #000000">

</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:2.00PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:2.00PT SOLID #000000">
	$
</TD>

	771&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:2.00PT SOLID #000000">

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:20PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	Earnings Per Common Share.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	The
	Corporation computes earnings per share (&#147;EPS&#148;) pursuant to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-class
</FONT>
	method. The
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-class
</FONT>
	method determines EPS for each class of common stock and
	participating securities according to dividends or dividend equivalents and their respective participation rights in undistributed earnings. The Corporation pays nonforfeitable dividend equivalents during the vesting period on its restricted stock
	awards and incentive stock awards made prior to 2016, which results in these being considered participating securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The numerator for basic
	and diluted earnings per common share is net earnings attributable to Martin Marietta, reduced by dividends and undistributed earnings attributable to the Corporation&#146;s unvested restricted stock awards and incentive stock awards issued prior to
	2016. The denominator for basic earnings per common share is the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding during the period. Diluted earnings per common share are computed assuming that the weighted-average number of common shares is
	increased by the conversion, using the treasury stock method, of awards issued to employees and nonemployee members of the Corporation&#146;s Board of Directors under certain stock-based compensation arrangements if the conversion is dilutive.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table reconciles the numerator and denominator for basic and diluted earnings per common
	share:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage107"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:9PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
	(continued)
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
	New Accounting Pronouncements.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	The
	Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued an accounting standard update on accounting for stock compensation. The new standard is effective January&nbsp;1, 2017 and requires all excess tax benefits and tax deficiencies to be
	recorded as income tax benefit or expense in the income statement in the period the awards vest or are settled as a discrete item. Additionally, any excess tax benefits will be reflected as an operating activity in the statement of cash flows.
	Further, any shares withheld for personal income taxes will be classified as a financing activity in the statement of cash flows. Although the adoption of the new standard does not have a cumulative effect, it will create volatility in the
	Corporation&#146;s income tax rate in periods when share-based compensation awards either vest or are exercised.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The FASB issued an accounting
	standard update that amends the accounting guidance on revenue recognition. The new standard intends to provide a more robust framework for addressing revenue issues, improve comparability of revenue recognition practices and improve disclosure
	requirements. The new standard is effective January&nbsp;1, 2018 and can be applied on a full retrospective or modified retrospective approach. The Corporation has completed its initial assessment of the provisions of the new standard and, at this
	time, does not expect the impact to be material to its results of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The FASB issued an accounting standard update on accounting for
	leases. The new standard requires lease rights and obligations arising from lease contracts, including existing and new arrangements, to be recognized as assets and liabilities on the balance sheet. The standard also requires additional disclosures
	by lessees and contains targeted changes to accounting by lessors. The new standard is effective January&nbsp;1, 2019, with early adoption permitted. The guidance is required to be adopted at the earliest period presented using a modified
	retrospective approach. The Corporation is currently assessing the impact of the updated standard on the Corporation&#146;s financial statements. The Corporation believes the updated standard will have a material effect on its balance sheet but has
	not quantified the impact at this time.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The FASB issued an accounting standard update on the classification of certain cash receipts and payments
	in the statement of cash flows intended to reduce diversity in practice. The guidance is effective January&nbsp;1, 2018, with early adoption permitted. The guidance is to be applied retrospectively to all periods
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	presented, but may be applied prospectively if retrospective application would be impracticable. The Corporation is currently evaluating the effect of the standard on its consolidated statements
	of cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	Note B: Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table shows the changes in goodwill by reportable segment and in total:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	Note C: Business Combinations
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:10PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In the first quarter 2016, the Corporation acquired the outstanding stock of Rocky Mountain Materials and Asphalt, Inc. and Rocky Mountain Premix, Inc.
	The acquisition provides more than 500&nbsp;million tons of mineral reserves and expands the Corporation&#146;s presence along the Front Range of the Rocky Mountains, home to 80% of Colorado&#146;s population. The acquired operations are reported
	through the West Group. The Corporation has recorded preliminary fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed; however, the transaction purchase consideration is subject to a normal post-closing working capital adjustment. Therefore,
	the measurement period for accounts receivable and goodwill remains open as of December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	During the third quarter 2016, the
	Corporation acquired the remaining interest in Ratliff
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Ready-Mix,
</FONT>
	L.P. (&#147;Ratliff&#148;), which operates ready mixed concrete plants in central Texas. These operations are reported in the West Group. Prior
	to the acquisition, the Corporation owned a 40% interest in Ratliff which was accounted for under the equity method. The Corporation was required to remeasure the existing 40% interest in Ratliff at fair value upon closing of the transaction,
	resulting in a gain of $5,863,000, which is recorded in other nonoperating income, net. The Corporation recorded preliminary fair values of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed; however, certain amounts are subject to change upon review of
	the seller&#146;s final tax return. Therefore, the measurement period for deferred income tax accounts and goodwill remains open as of December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The impact of these acquisitions on the operating results was not considered material; therefore, pro forma financial information is not included.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	Note D: Accounts Receivable, Net
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Depreciation, depletion and amortization expense related to property, plant and equipment was $268,935,000,
	$246,874,000 and $211,242,000 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Depreciation, depletion and amortization expense includes amortization of machinery and equipment under capital leases.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Interest cost of $3,543,000, $5,832,000 and $8,033,000 was capitalized during 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, $58,332,000 and $58,937,000, respectively, of the Aggregates business&#146; net property, plant and equipment were
	located in foreign countries, namely the Bahamas and Canada.
</P>

</B>

	&nbsp;&nbsp;1,506,153
</B>
</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation&#146;s 6.6% Senior Notes due 2018, 7% Debentures due 2025, 6.25% Senior Notes due 2037, 4.25% Senior
	Notes due 2024 and Floating Rate Notes due 2017 (collectively, the &#147;Senior Notes&#148;) are senior unsecured obligations of the Corporation, ranking equal in right of payment with the Corporation&#146;s existing and future unsubordinated
	indebtedness. Upon a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	change-of-control
</FONT>
</FONT>
	repurchase event and a resulting below-investment-grade credit rating, the Corporation would be required to make an offer to
	repurchase all outstanding Senior Notes, with the exception of the 7% Debentures due 2025, at a price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount of the Senior Notes, plus any accrued and unpaid interest to, but not including, the purchase date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Senior Notes are carried net of original issue discount, which is being amortized by the effective interest method over the life of the issue.
	The Senior Notes are redeemable prior to their respective maturity dates at a make-whole redemption price. The principal amount, effective interest rate and maturity date for the Corporation&#146;s Senior Notes are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<A NAME="eolPage110"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:9PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
	(continued)
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In connection with the issuance of its $300,000,000 Floating Rate Senior Notes due 2017 (the
	&#147;Floating Rate Notes&#148;) and its $400,000,000 4.25% Senior Notes due 2024 (the &#147;4.25% Senior Notes&#148;), the Corporation entered into an indenture, between the Corporation and Regions Bank, as trustee, and a Registration Rights
	Agreement, among the Corporation, Deutsche Bank Securities, Inc. and J.P. Morgan Securities, LLC, as representatives of the several initial purchasers named in Schedule I to the purchase agreement. The Floating Rate Notes bear interest at a rate
	equal to the three-month London Interbank Offered Rate (&#147;LIBOR&#148;) plus 1.10% and may not be redeemed prior to maturity. The 4.25% Senior Notes may be redeemed in whole or in part prior to their maturity at a make-whole redemption price.
	During the last 3 months prior to maturity, the 4.25% Senior Notes can be redeemed at par plus accrued and unpaid interest.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	On December&nbsp;5,
	2016, the Corporation entered into a new credit agreement with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as Administrative Agent, Branch Banking and Trust Company (&#147;BB&amp;T&#148;), Deutsche Bank Securities, Inc., SunTrust Bank, and Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., as
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Co-Syndication
</FONT>
	Agents, and the lenders party thereto (the &#147;Credit Agreement&#148;), which provides for a $700,000,000 five-year senior unsecured revolving facility (the &#147;Revolving Facility&#148;).
	Borrowings under the Revolving Facility bear interest, at the Corporation&#146;s option, at rates based upon LIBOR or a base rate, plus, for each rate, a margin determined in accordance with a ratings-based pricing grid. The Revolving Facility
	replaced the Corporation&#146;s credit agreement dated as of November&nbsp;9, 2013 with JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as Administrative Agent, BB&amp;T, Deutsche Bank Securities, Inc., SunTrust Bank, and Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., as
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Co-Syndication
</FONT>
	Agents, and the lenders party thereto (the &#147;Former Credit Agreement&#148;). The Former Credit Agreement had provided for a term loan and a revolving facility under which $210,937,500 and $0,
	respectively, were outstanding prior to entering into the Revolving Facility. The Revolving Facility is syndicated with the following banks:
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PT; MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Total
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	$
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="RIGHT">
	700,000&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX; ">
<TD COLSPAN="4" VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:2.00PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation&#146;s Credit Agreement requires the Corporation&#146;s ratio of consolidated net
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	debt-to-consolidated
</FONT>
</FONT>
	earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, depletion and amortization (&#147;EBITDA&#148;), as defined, for the trailing-twelve months (the
	&#147;Ratio&#148;) to not exceed 3.50x as of the end of any fiscal quarter, provided that the Corporation may exclude from the Ratio debt incurred in connection with certain acquisitions during the quarter or the three preceding quarters so long as
	the Ratio calculated without such exclusion does not exceed 3.75x. Additionally, if no amounts are outstanding under both the Revolving Facility and the trade receivable securitization facility (discussed later), consolidated debt, including debt
	for which the Corporation is a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-borrower
</FONT>
	(see Note N), may be reduced by the Corporation&#146;s unrestricted cash and cash equivalents in excess of $50,000,000, such reduction not to exceed $200,000,000, for
	purposes of the covenant calculation. The Corporation was in compliance with this Ratio at December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Revolving Facility expires
	on December&nbsp;5, 2021, with any outstanding principal amounts, together with interest accrued thereon, due in full on that date. Available borrowings under the Revolving Facility are reduced by any outstanding letters of credit issued by the
	Corporation under the Revolving Facility. At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, the Corporation had $2,507,000 of outstanding letters of credit issued under the Revolving Facility. The Corporation paid the bank group an upfront loan commitment fee
	that is being amortized over the life of the Revolving Facility. The Revolving Facility includes an annual facility fee.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:9PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
	(continued)
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation, through a wholly-owned special-purpose subsidiary, has a trade receivable securitization
	facility (the &#147;Trade Receivable Facility&#148;). On September&nbsp;28, 2016, the Corporation amended the Trade Receivable Facility to increase the borrowing capacity from $250,000,000 to $300,000,000 and extend the maturity to
	September&nbsp;27, 2017. The Trade Receivable Facility, with SunTrust Bank, Regions Bank, PNC Bank, N.A., The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Ltd., New York Branch, and certain other lenders that may become a party to the facility from time to time,
	is backed by eligible trade receivables, as defined. Borrowings are limited to the lesser of the facility limit or the borrowing base, as defined, of $333,302,000 and $282,258,000 at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. These receivables
	are originated by the Corporation and then sold or contributed to the wholly-owned special-purpose subsidiary. The Corporation continues to be responsible for the servicing and administration of the receivables purchased by the wholly-owned
	special-purpose subsidiary. Borrowings under the Trade Receivable Facility bear interest at a rate equal to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-month
</FONT>
	LIBOR plus 0.725%, subject to change in the event that this rate no longer reflects the
	lender&#146;s cost of lending. The Trade Receivable Facility contains a cross-default provision to the Corporation&#146;s other debt agreements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation&#146;s long-term debt maturities for the five years following Decmber&nbsp;31, 2016, and thereafter are:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation&#146;s $300,000,000 Floating Rate Notes mature June&nbsp;30, 2017. The Corporation has classified these
	obligations as noncurrent long-term debt on the consolidated balance sheets as it has the intent to refinance the notes on a long-term basis. For the debt maturity schedule, the notes are included in 2021.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation has a $5,000,000 short-term line of credit. No amounts were outstanding under this line of credit at December&nbsp;31, 2016 or 2015.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Accumulated other comprehensive loss includes the unamortized value of terminated forward starting
	interest rate swap agreements. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, the Corporation recognized $1,367,000, $1,280,000 and $1,188,000, respectively, as additional interest expense. The ongoing amortization of the terminated
	value of the forward starting interest rate swap agreements will increase annual interest expense by approximately $1,400,000 until the maturity of the 6.6% Senior Notes in 2018.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	Note H: Financial Instruments
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation&#146;s financial instruments include temporary cash investments, accounts receivable, notes receivable, bank overdraft, accounts
	payable, publicly-registered long-term notes, debentures and other long-term debt.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Temporary cash investments are placed primarily in money market
	funds and money market demand deposit accounts with the following financial institutions: BB&amp;T, Comerica Bank and Regions Bank. The Corporation&#146;s cash equivalents have maturities of less than three months. Due to the short maturity of these
	investments, they are carried on the consolidated balance sheets at cost, which approximates fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Accounts receivable are due from a large
	number of customers, primarily in the construction industry, and are dispersed across wide geographic and economic regions. However, accounts receivable are more heavily concentrated in certain states, namely Texas, Colorado, North Carolina, Iowa
	and Georgia. The estimated fair values of accounts receivable approximate their carrying amounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Notes receivable are primarily promissory notes
	with customers and are not publicly traded. Management estimates that the fair value of notes receivable approximates its carrying amount.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The
	bank overdraft represents amounts to be funded to financial institutions for checks that have cleared the bank. The estimated fair value of the bank overdraft approximates its carrying value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Accounts payable represent amounts owed to suppliers and vendors. The estimated fair value of accounts payable approximates its carrying amount due to
	the short-term nature of the payables.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	Martin
	Marietta&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The carrying values and fair values of the Corporation&#146;s long-term debt were $1,686,189,000 and
	$1,752,338,000, respectively, at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $1,568,774,000 and $1,625,193,000, respectively, at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The estimated fair value of the Corporation&#146;s publicly-registered long-term debt was estimated based on
	Level&nbsp;2 of the fair value hierarchy using quoted market prices. The estimated fair values of other borrowings, which primarily represent variable-rate debt, approximate their carrying amounts as the interest rates reset periodically.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The increase in 2016 federal current tax expense is primarily attributable to an increase in earnings; while, in
	comparison to 2015, the benefit from the utilization of net operating loss (&#147;NOL&#148;) carryforwards acquired in the 2014 purchase of TXI lowered current tax expense. The utilization of NOL carryforwards primarily attributed to the increase in
	federal deferred tax expense in 2015, although some benefits were also recognized in 2016 and 2014. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, the benefit related to the utilization of federal NOL carryforwards, reflected in current
	tax expense, was $11,852,000, $156,554,000 and $16,940,000, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2014, excess tax benefits
	attributable to stock-based compensation transactions that were recorded to shareholders&#146; equity amounted to $6,792,000 and $2,508,000, respectively. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the realized tax benefit for stock-based
	compensation transactions was $871,000 less than the amounts estimated during the vesting periods, resulting in a decrease in the pool of excess tax credits.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, foreign pretax earnings were $3,865,000. For the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, foreign pretax loss was $1,175,000 and $10,557,000, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation&#146;s effective income tax
	rate on continuing operations varied from the statutory United States income tax rate because of the following permanent tax differences:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For income tax purposes, the statutory depletion deduction is calculated as a percentage of sales, subject to certain
	limitations. Due to these limitations, the impact of changes in the sales volumes and earnings may not proportionately affect the Corporation&#146;s statutory depletion deduction and the corresponding impact on the effective income tax rate on
	continuing operations. The growth in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-depletable
</FONT>
	income has resulted in a reduced impact on the effective income tax rate related to the statutory depletion deduction.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The state tax impact on the effective income tax rate has decreased due to changes in apportionment of taxable income to states with lower tax rates
	and the reduction in certain states&#146; statutory tax rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation is entitled to receive a 9% tax deduction related to income from
	domestic (i.e., United States) production activities. The deduction reduced income tax expense and increased consolidated net earnings by $13,583,000, or $0.21 per diluted share, in 2016; $222,000, or less than $0.01 per diluted share, in 2015; and
	$3,239,000, or $0.05 per diluted share, in 2014. The impact on the 2015 and 2014 effective income tax rate was limited by the significant utilization of NOL carryforwards.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;

<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2015 and 2014, the Corporation wrote off goodwill not deductible for income tax purposes as part of
	the sale of certain operations. In addition, the Corporation incurred certain compensation and transaction expenses, primarily in 2014 in connection with the TXI acquisition, that are not deductible for income tax purposes and therefore increased
	the effective income tax rate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The principal components of the Corporation&#146;s deferred tax assets and liabilities are as follows:

	$

<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX; ">

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:22PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The increase in the net deferred tax liability is primarily a result of deferred taxes recorded in conjunction with
	stock acquisitions and the utilization of Alternative Minimum Tax (&#147;AMT&#148;) credit carryforwards.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Deferred tax assets for employee
	benefits result from the temporary differences between the deductions for pension and postretirement obligations, incentive compensation and stock-based compensation transactions. For financial reporting purposes, such amounts are expensed based on
	authoritative accounting guidance. For income tax purposes, amounts related to pension and postretirement obligations and incentive compensation are deductible as funded. Amounts related to stock-based compensation transactions are deductible for
	income tax purposes upon vesting or exercise of the underlying award.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation had domestic federal and state NOL carryforwards of $220,532,000 (federal $0; state
	$220,532,000) and $273,251,000 (federal $33,863,000; state $239,388,000) at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. These carryforwards have various expiration dates through 2036. At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, deferred tax assets
	associated with these carryforwards were $10,507,000 and $11,448,000, respectively, net of unrecognized tax benefits, for which valuation allowances of $8,303,000 and $8,690,000, respectively, were recorded. The Corporation recorded a $3,714,000
	valuation reserve in 2015 for certain domestic NOL carryforwards, which was driven by the sale of the California cement operations. The Corporation also had domestic tax credit carryforwards of $1,441,000 and $3,179,000 at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and
	2015, respectively, which expire in 2018. At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, deferred tax assets associated with these carryforwards were $937,000 and $2,509,000, respectively, net of unrecognized tax benefits, for which valuation allowances of
	$218,000 and $277,000, respectively, were recorded. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Corporation also had an AMT credit carryforward of $17,192,000, which does not expire. The deferred tax asset associated with this carryforward, net of unrecognized
	tax benefits, was $2,771,000.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Deferred tax liabilities for property, plant and equipment result from accelerated depreciation methods being used
	for income tax purposes as compared with the straight-line method for financial reporting purposes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Deferred tax liabilities related to goodwill
	and other intangibles reflect the cessation of goodwill amortization for financial reporting purposes, while amortization continues for income tax purposes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation provides deferred taxes, as required, on the undistributed net earnings of all
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	subsidiaries for which the indefinite reversal criterion has not been met. The Corporation expects to reinvest permanently the earnings from its wholly-owned Canadian subsidiary and accordingly, has not provided deferred taxes on the
	subsidiary&#146;s undistributed net earnings. The wholly-owned Canadian subsidiary&#146;s undistributed net earnings are estimated to be $35,392,000 at December&nbsp;31, 2016. The unrecognized deferred tax liability for temporary differences related
	to the investment in the wholly-owned Canadian subsidiary is estimated to be $1,872,000 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#4D5358">
<B>
	Martin
	Marietta&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;
</B>

</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#4D5358">

</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:9PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
	(continued)
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table summarizes the Corporation&#146;s unrecognized tax benefits, excluding interest and
	correlative effects:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:16PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, the unrecognized tax benefits assumed with acquisition represented positions
	acquired with TXI.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, unrecognized tax benefits of $11,603,000, $7,975,000 and $9,362,000, respectively,
	related to interest accruals and permanent income tax differences, net of federal tax benefits, would have favorably affected the Corporation&#146;s effective income tax rate if recognized.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Unrecognized tax benefits are reversed as a discrete event if an examination of applicable tax returns is not initiated by a federal or state tax
	authority within the statute of limitations or upon effective settlement with federal or state tax authorities. Management believes its accrual for unrecognized tax benefits is sufficient to cover uncertain tax positions reviewed during audits by
	taxing authorities. The Corporation anticipates that it is reasonably possible that its unrecognized tax benefits may decrease up to $3,935,000, excluding indirect benefits, during the twelve months ending December&nbsp;31, 2017 due to the
	expiration of the statute of limitations for the 2012 and 2013 tax years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, $2,364,000 or $0.04
	per diluted share, and $687,000 or $0.01 per diluted share, respectively, were reversed into income upon the statute of limitations expiration for the 2010 and 2011 tax years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation&#146;s open tax years subject to federal, state or foreign examinations are 2010 through 2016.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	Note J: Retirement Plans, Postretirement and Postemployment Benefits
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation sponsors defined benefit retirement plans that cover substantially all employees. Additionally, the Corporation provides other
	postretirement benefits for certain employees, including medical benefits for retirees and their spouses and retiree life insurance. The Corporation also provides certain benefits, such as disability benefits, to former or inactive employees after
	employment but before retirement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The measurement date for the Corporation&#146;s defined benefit plans, postretirement benefit plans and
	postemployment benefit plans is December 31.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
<B>
<I>
	Defined Benefit Retirement
	Plans.
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Retirement plan assets are invested in listed stocks, bonds, hedge funds, real estate and cash equivalents. Defined retirement benefits for salaried employees are based on each employee&#146;s
	years of service and average compensation for a specified period of time before retirement. Defined retirement benefits for hourly employees are generally stated amounts for specified periods of service.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation sponsors a Supplemental Excess Retirement Plan (&#147;SERP&#148;) that generally provides for the payment of retirement benefits in
	excess of allowable Internal Revenue Code limits. The SERP generally provides for a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	lump-sum
</FONT>
	payment of vested benefits. When these benefit payments exceed the sum of the service and interest costs for the
	SERP during a year, the Corporation recognizes a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pro-rata
</FONT>
	portion of the SERP&#146;s unrecognized actuarial loss as settlement expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The net periodic retirement benefit cost of defined benefit plans includes the following components:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The expected return on assets is based on the fair value of the plan assets. The termination benefit
	charge represents the increased benefits payable to former TXI executives as part of their
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	change-in-control
</FONT>
</FONT>
	agreements.

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	Expected long-term rate of return on assets
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<B>
	7.00%
</B>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
	7.00%
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
	7.00%&nbsp;&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The expected long-term rate of return on assets is based on a building-block approach, whereby the components are
	weighted based on the allocation of pension plan assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For 2016 and 2015, the Corporation estimated the remaining lives of participants in the
	pension plans using the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	RP-2014
</FONT>
	Base Table. The Corporation used mortality improvement scale
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	MP-2016
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	BB-2D
</FONT>
	for the years 2016
	and 2015, respectively. The change in mortality improvement scale in 2016 did not have a material impact on the projected benefit obligation. The white-collar table was used for salaried participants and the blue-collar table, reflecting the
	experience of the Corporation&#146;s participants, was used for hourly participants.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The target allocation for 2016 and the actual pension plan
	asset allocation by asset class are as follows:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation&#146;s investment strategy is for approximately 50% of equity securities to be invested in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mid-sized
</FONT>
	to large capitalization U.S. funds with the remaining to be invested in small capitalization, emerging markets and international funds. Debt securities, or fixed income investments, are invested in funds
	benchmarked to the Barclays U.S. Aggregate Bond Index.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">

	&nbsp;

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Level&nbsp;3 real estate investments are stated at estimated fair value, which is the price that would be received to
	sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. The fair values of real estate investments generally do not reflect transaction costs which may be incurred upon disposition
	of the real estate investments and do not necessarily represent the prices at which the real estate investments would be sold or repaid, since market prices of real estate investments can only be determined by negotiation between a willing buyer and
	seller. An independent valuation consultant is employed to determine the fair value of the real estate investments. The value of hedge funds is based on the values of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	sub-fund
</FONT>
	investments. In determining
	the fair value of each
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	sub-fund&#146;s
</FONT>
	investment, the hedge funds&#146; Board of Trustees uses the values provided by the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	sub-funds
</FONT>
	and any other considerations that
	may, in its judgment, increase or decrease such estimated value.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">

	Martin

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2016 and 2015, the Corporation made combined pension and SERP contributions of $44,763,000 and $53,924,000,
	respectively. The Corporation currently estimates that it will contribute $32,537,000 to its pension and SERP plans in 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
<B>
<I>
	Defined Contribution Plans.
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The Corporation maintains defined contribution plans that cover substantially all employees. These plans, qualified under Section 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code, are retirement savings and investment plans for the
	Corporation&#146;s salaried and hourly employees. Under certain provisions of these plans, the Corporation, at established rates, matches employees&#146; eligible contributions. The Corporation&#146;s matching obligations were $13,235,000 in 2016,
	$12,444,000 in 2015 and $8,602,000 in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#49B28F">
<B>
<I>
	Postemployment Benefits.
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
	The Corporation had accrued postemployment benefits of $1,146,000 and $1,267,000 at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	Note K: Stock-Based Compensation
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The shareholders approved, on May&nbsp;19, 2016, the Martin Marietta Amended and Restated Stock-Based Award Plan. The Martin Marietta Materials, Inc.
	Stock-Based Award Plan, as amended from time to time (along with the Amended Omnibus Securities Award Plan, originally approved in 1994, the &#147;Plans&#148;) is still effective for awards made prior to 2017. The Corporation has been authorized by
	the Board of Directors to repurchase shares of the Corporation&#146;s common stock for issuance under the stock-based award plans (see Note M).
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:8.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#4D5358">
<B>
	Martin
	Marietta&nbsp;&nbsp;|&nbsp;&nbsp;
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#0085CD">
	Page 32
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" COLOR="#4D5358">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage119"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:9PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
	(continued)
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:10PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The Corporation grants restricted stock awards under the Plans to a group of executive officers, key
	personnel and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employee
</FONT>
	Board of Directors. The vesting of certain restricted stock awards is based on certain performance criteria over a specified period of time. In addition, certain awards are granted
	to individuals to encourage retention and motivate key employees. These awards generally vest if the employee is continuously employed over a specified period of time and require no payment from the employee. Awards granted to nonemployee Board of
	Directors vest immediately.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Additionally, an incentive stock plan has been adopted under the Plans whereby certain participants may elect to use
	up to 50% of their annual incentive compensation
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	to acquire units representing shares of the Corporation&#146;s common stock at a 20% discount to the market value on the date of the incentive compensation award. Certain executive officers are
	required to participate in the incentive stock plan at certain minimum levels. Participants earn the right to receive unrestricted shares of common stock in an amount equal to their respective units generally at the end of a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	34-month
</FONT>
	period of additional employment from the date of award or at retirement beginning at age 62. All rights of ownership of the common stock convey to the participants upon the issuance of their respective
	shares at the end of the ownership-vesting period, with the exception of dividend equivalents that are paid on the units during the vesting period.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:14PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table summarizes
	information for restricted stock awards and incentive compensation awards as of December&nbsp;31, 2016:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The weighted-average grant-date fair value of service-based restricted stock awards granted during 2016,
	2015 and 2014 was $128.48, $154.26 and $126.88, respectively. The weighted average grant-date fair value of performance-based restricted stock awards granted during 2016, 2015 and 2014 was $124.41, $108.53 and $129.14, respectively. The
	weighted-average grant-date fair value of incentive compensation awards granted during 2016, 2015 and 2014 was $124.41, $108.53 and $109.17, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The aggregate intrinsic values for restricted stock awards and incentive compensation awards at December&nbsp;31, 2016 were $92,740,000 and $5,270,000,
	respectively, and were based on the closing price of the Corporation&#146;s common stock at December&nbsp;31, 2016, which was $221.53. The aggregate intrinsic values of restricted stock awards distributed during the years ended December&nbsp;31,
	2016, 2015 and 2014 were
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:2%; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	$9,738,000, $11,387,000 and $3,555,000, respectively. The aggregate intrinsic values of incentive compensation awards distributed during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014 were
	$1,941,000, $983,000 and $584,000, respectively. The aggregate intrinsic values for distributed awards were based on the closing prices of the Corporation&#146;s common stock on the dates of distribution.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Under the Plans, prior to 2016, the Corporation granted options to employees to purchase its common stock at a price equal to the closing market value
	at the date of grant. Options become exercisable in four annual installments beginning one year after date of grant. Options granted starting 2013 expire ten years after the grant date while outstanding options granted prior to 2013 expire eight
	years after the grant date.
</P>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; HEIGHT:0PT; FONT-SIZE:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<FONT COLOR="#0085CD">
<B>
	NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL; FONT-SIZE:9PT" COLOR="#0085CD">
	(continued)

</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:24PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV STYLE="POSITION:RELATIVE;FLOAT:LEFT; WIDTH:48%;PADDING-RIGHT:1%;PADDING-BOTTOM:8PT;OVERFLOW:HIDDEN;PADDING-TOP:3PT">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In connection with the TXI acquisition, the Corporation issued 821,282 Martin Marietta stock options
	(&#147;Replacement Options&#148;) to holders of outstanding TXI stock options at the acquisition date. The Corporation issued 0.7 Replacement Options for each outstanding TXI stock option, and the Replacement Option prices reflected the exchange
	ratio. The Replacement Options will expire on the original contractual dates when the TXI stock options were initially issued. Consistent with the terms of the Corporation&#146;s other outstanding stock options, Replacement Options expire
	90&nbsp;days after employment is terminated.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Prior to 2009, each nonemployee Board of Director member received 3,000
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-qualified
</FONT>
	stock options annually. These options have an exercise price equal to the market value at the date of grant, vested immediately and expire ten years from the grant date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT; FONT-FAMILY:ARIAL" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
